T6.question:
Can you tell if the people in the photograph are Jewish? 

Often, though not always, Jewish people will be marked with a badge, an armband, or they are dressed in a traditional Jewish attire. Sometimes there will be Jewish artefacts next to them (Menorah, Hebrew books, Jewish tombstones, etc.).

T28.instruction: If you can, please transcribe the text here.

answers.label: Snap-shot: was taken clandestinely or in a haste (holding the camera at the waste, or in a hidden place). The subjects are probably not aware of being photographed
A "touristic" photograph: while on vacation, a hike, or during the military service--probably to be viewed in private (can also document violence, in ghettos, for instance)
A German propaganda photography: designated to display the achievements or the ideological convictions of Nazism

A photograph aims to show Jewish *resistance* (can also be cultural or spiritual resistance, for instance by maintaining cultural or religious events, community-supportive institutions, continuity of routines under crisis, etc.)
Private photography: of the private environment and to be viewed in private (among family or friends, not in public)
Journalistic-documentary photography: to document and report on the photographed reality

T29.question: How would you describe the genre or style of the photograph (if you are not sure, feel free to guess).

answers.label: Transport (expulsion) of Jews or waiting to be transported (a group of people, normally with suitcases, possibly next to tracks or trains)
Daily life under Nazi rule (in Germany) or occupation (elsewhere) -- not in the ghetto
Life and death in the ghetto (including the destruction of the ghetto)
Slave labor (normally in a ghetto or a camp)
Jewish life in Europe before the war (or in Germany before 1933).
Partisans or other militia forces that fought against the German occupation
Displaced Persons camps after the war
Other, or I do not know

Jewish life before the beginning of the war
